epidemiology: Affects approximately 1% of the global population. Most common neurological disorder after stroke. Peaks in childhood and elderly.
treatment_protocol: EEG + MRI → AEDs → Surgery for refractory cases

epidemiology: Accounts for ~85% of all strokes. Leading cause of long-term disability globally. Incidence increases with age.
treatment_protocol: CT → tPA if eligible → Secondary prevention

epidemiology: Second most common neurodegenerative disorder after Alzheimer’s. Affects 1% of people over 60 years. M:F ratio is 3:2.
treatment_protocol: Clinical → Levodopa trial → Monitor response

epidemiology: Autoimmune demyelinating disease. Prevalence highest in young adult females. Common in temperate climates.

emergency_markers: Acute MS flare with motor symptoms

treatment_protocol: MRI + CSF → Steroids → Start DMT

epidemiology: Autoimmune disorder of neuromuscular junction. Bimodal distribution: young females and older males. Incidence ~20/100,000.
treatment_protocol: AChR Ab → Anticholinesterase → Thymectomy if indicated

epidemiology: Most common cause of dementia worldwide. Affects ~10% of people over age 65. Risk increases with age and family history.
treatment_protocol: Assess cognition → Start meds → Monitor decline

epidemiology: Progressive motor neuron disease affecting 2 per 100,000 people annually. Median survival 3–5 years from symptom onset.
treatment_protocol: EMG → Start riluzole → Monitor respiratory status

epidemiology: Acute immune-mediated demyelinating polyneuropathy, often post-infection. Incidence ~1–2 per 100,000/year.
treatment_protocol: LP + EMG → IVIG or plasma exchange → Monitor

epidemiology: Affects ~12 per 100,000 annually. More common in women >50. Often idiopathic, or due to vascular compression or MS.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Start carbamazepine → Refer if refractory

epidemiology: Autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder. Onset 30–50 years. Prevalence 5–10 per 100,000. Caused by CAG repeat expansion.
treatment_protocol: Genetic confirmation → Symptom-based management

epidemiology: Most common primary headache disorder, affecting up to 70% of the population. More common in women. Peaks in the 30s.
treatment_protocol: Clinical dx → NSAIDs → Preventives for chronic

epidemiology: Affects ~12% of the global population. More common in females. Onset typically in adolescence or early adulthood.
treatment_protocol: Clinical → Abortive meds → Preventive for frequent attacks

epidemiology: Rare but extremely painful. Affects ~0.1% of population, mostly young to middle-aged men. Tends to occur in clusters (weeks to months).

additional: MRI brain to rule out secondary causes

treatment_protocol: Acute tx → Oxygen + triptan → Verapamil if chronic

epidemiology: Large vessel vasculitis in older adults, especially females >50. Associated with polymyalgia rheumatica.
treatment_protocol: Suspect → Start steroids → Biopsy within 2 weeks

epidemiology: Most common entrapment neuropathy. Prevalence ~3% of adults. More common in women and manual laborers.

timeline.symptom: Numbness in thumb, index, and middle fingers

treatment_protocol: Splint + NCS → Inject or decompress surgically

epidemiology: Most common cause of acute unilateral facial paralysis. Annual incidence ~20–30 per 100,000. Peaks between ages 15–45.
treatment_protocol: Start steroids within 72 hrs → Add antivirals if needed

epidemiology: Rare cause of dementia. Triad: gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and dementia. More common in elderly. Often idiopathic.
treatment_protocol: MRI + LP → Shunt if responsive

epidemiology: Rare inflammatory spinal cord condition. Incidence ~1–8 per million annually. Can be idiopathic or secondary to autoimmune disease.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Steroids → Plasma exchange if needed

epidemiology: Affects ~2–7% of the population. Common in diabetics and elderly. Can be sensory, motor, or mixed.
treatment_protocol: Identify cause → Treat neuropathy → Prevent complications

epidemiology: Most common cause of spinal cord dysfunction in older adults. Degenerative changes compress spinal cord.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Surgical consult → Rehab post-op

epidemiology: Affects ~5–10% of adults. More common in women and with increasing age. Often idiopathic, but may be secondary.
treatment_protocol: Check ferritin → Start dopamine agonist if needed

epidemiology: Chronic sleep disorder affecting ~1 in 2,000 people. Often begins in adolescence or early adulthood. Caused by hypocretin deficiency.
treatment_protocol: Polysomnogram → Modafinil → Address cataplexy

epidemiology: Most common movement disorder. Affects ~4% of adults >65 years. Often familial with autosomal dominant inheritance.
treatment_protocol: Start propranolol or primidone → Consider DBS if severe

epidemiology: Primarily affects obese women of childbearing age. Incidence ~1–2 per 100,000 annually.
treatment_protocol: MRI + LP → Acetazolamide → Monitor vision

epidemiology: Rare neurodegenerative disorder with parkinsonian or cerebellar features. Onset ~50–60 years. Poor prognosis, survival ~6–10 years.
treatment_protocol: Supportive care → Manage symptoms → Monitor progression

epidemiology: Atypical parkinsonian disorder. Onset typically after age 60. Prevalence ~5–6 per 100,000.
treatment_protocol: Supportive care → Prevent complications → Monitor progression

epidemiology: Rare progressive neurodegenerative disorder. Onset typically between 60–70 years.
treatment_protocol: Supportive therapies → Monitor progression

epidemiology: Chronic counterpart of Guillain-Barré syndrome. Prevalence ~1–9 per 100,000. Affects all age groups.
treatment_protocol: NCS + CSF → Start IVIG or steroids → Monitor response

epidemiology: Involuntary contractions of facial muscles on one side. More common in middle-aged women.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Botulinum → Consider surgery if refractory

epidemiology: Facial pain syndrome affecting ~12 per 100,000 annually. More common in women and older adults.

important: MRI brain to rule out causes

treatment_protocol: MRI → Start carbamazepine → Surgery if refractory

epidemiology: Rare subtype of migraine with aura originating from brainstem or both hemispheres. Affects adolescents and young adults, more common in females.
treatment_protocol: Rule out secondary causes → Preventive therapy → Acute migraine management

epidemiology: Progressive neurodegenerative disease affecting upper and lower motor neurons. Incidence: ~2 per 100,000/year. Onset typically in 50s–60s.

emergency_markers: Sudden inability to swallow or speak

treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Start Riluzole → Multidisciplinary care

epidemiology: Acute neurological emergency due to thiamine deficiency, commonly in alcoholics or malnourished patients.
treatment_protocol: Thiamine IV before glucose → Supportive care → Treat underlying cause

epidemiology: Autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder. Onset: 30–50 years. Prevalence: ~5 per 100,000.
treatment_protocol: Genetic confirmation → Supportive + symptomatic management

epidemiology: Most common type of primary headache. Lifetime prevalence up to 80%. More common in women.
treatment_protocol: Exclude red flags → NSAIDs → Preventive meds if chronic

epidemiology: Inflammatory vasculitis affecting medium to large arteries. Incidence increases with age; more common in women >50 years.
treatment_protocol: Start steroids → Confirm with biopsy → Taper based on ESR/CRP

epidemiology: Neurotoxic state from acute hypertension or immunosuppressive therapy. Reversible with prompt treatment.
treatment_protocol: Control BP → Manage seizures → Repeat imaging to confirm resolution

epidemiology: Rare demyelinating condition caused by rapid correction of hyponatremia. Often fatal or disabling.

emergency_markers: Rapid neuro deterioration post sodium correction

treatment_protocol: Preventive → Slow sodium correction < 8 mEq/L/day

epidemiology: Raised ICP without tumor. Common in obese women of reproductive age.
treatment_protocol: MRI + LP → Start acetazolamide → Consider surgical options

disease: Subacute Combined Degeneration of the Spinal Cord
epidemiology: Neurological complication of vitamin B12 deficiency. Often seen in vegetarians or patients with pernicious anemia.
treatment_protocol: Confirm B12 deficiency → Start IM B12 → Monitor recovery

epidemiology: Atypical Parkinsonism with autonomic failure and cerebellar/pyramidal features. Onset typically in 50s–60s, rare but progressive.

important: MRI brain (putaminal changes, hot cross bun sign)

definitive: Limited – Levodopa trial may be ineffective

treatment_protocol: Rule out mimics → Symptomatic treatment → Monitor progression

epidemiology: Chronic sleep disorder affecting ~1 in 2,000 people. Usually begins in adolescence or early adulthood.
treatment_protocol: Confirm via PSG + MSLT → Modafinil → Add sodium oxybate if cataplexy

epidemiology: Affects ~5–10% of the population. More common in women and with increasing age.
treatment_protocol: Treat underlying cause → Dopaminergic agent → Monitor for augmentation

epidemiology: Affects elderly. Characterized by triad: gait disturbance, dementia, and urinary incontinence. Often misdiagnosed.
treatment_protocol: MRI + tap test → VP shunt → Monitor improvement

epidemiology: Autosomal dominant condition with multisystem involvement. Incidence ~1 in 3,000 births.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Surveillance → Treat complications

epidemiology: Autoimmune disorder affecting neuromuscular junction. Bimodal age distribution: women <40, men >60.
treatment_protocol: Diagnosis confirmation → Anticholinesterase + steroids → Thymectomy if thymoma

epidemiology: Acute immune-mediated polyneuropathy. Incidence: ~1–2/100,000/year. Often post-infectious.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Start IVIG/plasmapheresis → Supportive monitoring

epidemiology: Group of hereditary ataxias. Autosomal dominant inheritance. Onset varies by subtype.
treatment_protocol: Genetic diagnosis → Supportive care → Rehabilitation focus

epidemiology: Common complication of diabetes. Affects up to 50% of long-term diabetics.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose → Control sugar → Add neuropathic pain treatment

epidemiology: Most common cause of sporadic fatal viral encephalitis in adults. Caused by HSV-1.
treatment_protocol: Start Acyclovir early → Confirm with CSF PCR → Continue IV therapy 14–21 days
